Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Transfer Learning Based Quality Improvement in Spatially-Temporally Complex Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is to develop "transfer learning" based methodologies for quality improvement of manufacturing systems featured by a high product variety and short life cycles (called spatially-temporally complex systems). Such systems typically exist in semiconductor and renewable-energy manufacturing industries. The methodological innovation - transfer learning - refers to the capability of leveraging the knowledge gained during quality control of one process (or past generations of a process) for quality control of other processes (or a new generation). A body of statistically rigorous and computationally efficient transfer learning based methods will be developed to achieve various quality control objectives such as process modeling, monitoring, root cause diagnosis, sensor uncertainty modeling, and sensor placement. Integrated with the research is an ambitious education plan aiming at equipping future workforce with new science and engineering knowledge and associated skills in quality improvement.

If successful, the results of this research will significantly expedite the learning curve in quality improvement of each process in a manufacturing system through effective knowledge transfer from other processes and past generations. This will enable robust, real-time and even proactive quality control decision making to keep up with rapid product proliferation and generation changes. Through validation and application in semiconductor and solar energy manufacturing, this research will provide breakthrough technologies to significantly improve the quality, productivity, and cost-effectiveness of these industries. The research methodologies are also transferrable to the study of other systems such as health care delivery, human brain, and biological systems. A broad array of educational activities will be pursued, including new course development, industrial training sessions, undergraduate and minority students involvement, and K-12 students and teachers outreach. Research and education programs will be established through strong international collaboration to achieve global impact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: This project developed new transfer learning methodologies for quality control of complex manufacturing systems. Transfer learning is a natural human ability that leverages past experience when learning a new skill. Statistical and machine learning models to mimic human transfer learning ability in data modeling for quality control of manufacturing systems are novel, and are a major goal of research development in this CAREER project. Specifically, this project has developed transfer learning methodologies in the following areas: (1) We developed a novel spatial transfer learning model to allow for learning of process-quality relationships between production processes that produce different products. (2) We developed a temporal transfer learning model to allow for learning and updating of process-quality relationships across different generations of a product. (3) We developed a transfer learning network model to identify interactions between high-dimensional process and quality variables to map out the manufacturing complexity and infer causality. This allowed for control and intervention for improving the quality and performance of the system. (4) We developed a continuous monitoring and change detection algorithm based on transfer learning-enabled process-quality relationship identification to timely detect anomaly in the process and trigger corrective actions. This project produced ten journal publications and a dozen conference presentations at INFORMS and ISERC. 

Broader impacts: The research methodology has been applied to a number of application areas including semiconductor manufacturing and health care. Partnerships with these industries have been established. One Ph.D. student was supported and the project also attracted several undergraduate students to participate in the research. The research methodology, real-world datasets, and application case studies have been incorporated into the Quality Control and Advanced Quality Control courses the PI has been teaching.
